trans-unit.source: Operations on DNS zones | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Operations on DNS zones | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: You can manage DNS zones using Azure Powershell cmdlets or CLI. How to update, delete and create DNS zones on Azure DNS
trans-unit.target: You can manage DNS zones using Azure Powershell cmdlets or CLI. How to update, delete and create DNS zones on Azure DNS

trans-unit.source: This guide will show how to manage your DNS zone.
trans-unit.target: This guide will show how to manage your DNS zone.

trans-unit.source: It will help understanding the sequence of operations to be done in order to administer your DNS zone.
trans-unit.target: It will help understanding the sequence of operations to be done in order to administer your DNS zone.

trans-unit.source: To create a new DNS zone to host your domain, use the New-AzureDnsZone cmdlet:
trans-unit.target: To create a new DNS zone to host your domain, use the New-AzureDnsZone cmdlet:

trans-unit.source: The operation creates a new DNS zone in Azure DNS and returns a local object corresponding to that zone.
trans-unit.target: The operation creates a new DNS zone in Azure DNS and returns a local object corresponding to that zone.

trans-unit.source: You can optionally specify an array of Azure Resource Manager tags, for more information see <linkText>Etags and Tags</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: You can optionally specify an array of Azure Resource Manager tags, for more information see <linkText>Etags and Tags</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The name of the zone must be unique within the resource group, and the zone must not exist already, otherwise the operation will fail.
trans-unit.target: The name of the zone must be unique within the resource group, and the zone must not exist already, otherwise the operation will fail.

trans-unit.source: The same zone name can be re-used in a different resource group or a different Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: The same zone name can be re-used in a different resource group or a different Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: Where multiple zones share the same name, each instance will be assigned different name server addresses, and only one instance can be delegated from the parent domain.
trans-unit.target: Where multiple zones share the same name, each instance will be assigned different name server addresses, and only one instance can be delegated from the parent domain.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>Delegate a Domain to Azure DNS</linkText><title></title> for more information.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Delegate a Domain to Azure DNS</linkText><title></title> for more information.

trans-unit.source: To retrieve a DNS zone, use the Get-AzureDnsZone cmdlet:
trans-unit.target: To retrieve a DNS zone, use the Get-AzureDnsZone cmdlet:

trans-unit.source: The operation returns a DNS zone object corresponding to an existing zone in Azure DNS.
trans-unit.target: The operation returns a DNS zone object corresponding to an existing zone in Azure DNS.

trans-unit.source: This object contains data about the zone (such as the number of record sets), but does not contain the record sets themselves.
trans-unit.target: This object contains data about the zone (such as the number of record sets), but does not contain the record sets themselves.

trans-unit.source: By omitting the zone name from Get-AzureDnsZone, you can enumerate all zones in a resource group:
trans-unit.target: By omitting the zone name from Get-AzureDnsZone, you can enumerate all zones in a resource group:

trans-unit.source: Changes to a DNS zone resource can be made using Set-AzureDnsZone.
trans-unit.target: Changes to a DNS zone resource can be made using Set-AzureDnsZone.

trans-unit.source: This does not update any of the DNS record sets within the zone (see <linkText>How to Manage DNS records</linkText><title></title>).
trans-unit.target: This does not update any of the DNS record sets within the zone (see <linkText>How to Manage DNS records</linkText><title></title>).

trans-unit.source: It is only used to update properties of the zone resource itself.
trans-unit.target: It is only used to update properties of the zone resource itself.

trans-unit.source: This is currently limited to the Azure Resource Manager ‘tags’ for the zone resource.
trans-unit.target: This is currently limited to the Azure Resource Manager ‘tags’ for the zone resource.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>Etags and Tags</linkText><title></title> for more information.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Etags and Tags</linkText><title></title> for more information.

trans-unit.source: Use one of the following two ways to update DNS zone:
trans-unit.target: Use one of the following two ways to update DNS zone:

trans-unit.source: Specify the zone using the zone name and resource group.
trans-unit.target: Specify the zone using the zone name and resource group.

trans-unit.source: Specify the zone using a $zone object from Get-AzureDnsZone:
trans-unit.target: Specify the zone using a $zone object from Get-AzureDnsZone:

trans-unit.source: When using Set-AzureDnsZone with a $zone object, ‘Etag’ checks will be used to ensure concurrent changes are not overwritten.
trans-unit.target: When using Set-AzureDnsZone with a $zone object, ‘Etag’ checks will be used to ensure concurrent changes are not overwritten.

trans-unit.source: You can use the optional ‘-Overwrite’ switch to suppress these checks.
trans-unit.target: You can use the optional ‘-Overwrite’ switch to suppress these checks.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>Etags and Tags</linkText><title></title> for more information.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Etags and Tags</linkText><title></title> for more information.

trans-unit.source: DNS zones can be deleted using the Remove-AzureDnsZone cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: DNS zones can be deleted using the Remove-AzureDnsZone cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: Before deleting a DNS zone in Azure DNS, you will need to delete all records sets, except for the NS and SOA records at the root of the zone that were created automatically when the zone was created.
trans-unit.target: Before deleting a DNS zone in Azure DNS, you will need to delete all records sets, except for the NS and SOA records at the root of the zone that were created automatically when the zone was created.

trans-unit.source: Use one of the following two ways to remove a DNS zone:
trans-unit.target: Use one of the following two ways to remove a DNS zone:

trans-unit.source: Specify the zone using the zone name and resource group name:
trans-unit.target: Specify the zone using the zone name and resource group name:

trans-unit.source: This operation has an optional ‘-Force’ switch which suppresses the prompt to confirm you want to remove the DNS zone.
trans-unit.target: This operation has an optional ‘-Force’ switch which suppresses the prompt to confirm you want to remove the DNS zone.

trans-unit.source: Specify the zone using a $zone object from Get-AzureDnsZone:
trans-unit.target: Specify the zone using a $zone object from Get-AzureDnsZone:

trans-unit.source: The ‘-Force’ switch is the same as in Option 1.
trans-unit.target: The ‘-Force’ switch is the same as in Option 1.

trans-unit.source:
As with ‘Set-AzureDnsZone’, specifying the zone using a $zone object enables ‘etag’ checks to ensure concurrent changes are not deleted.
The optional ‘-Overwrite’ flag suppresses these checks. See Etags and Tags for more information.
trans-unit.target:
As with ‘Set-AzureDnsZone’, specifying the zone using a $zone object enables ‘etag’ checks to ensure concurrent changes are not deleted.
The optional ‘-Overwrite’ flag suppresses these checks. See Etags and Tags for more information.

trans-unit.source: The zone object can also be piped instead of being passed as a parameter:
trans-unit.target: The zone object can also be piped instead of being passed as a parameter:

trans-unit.target: <linkText>Manage DNS records</linkText><title></title>
